data.text: @doctorsaluja @UniofOxford @fitterhappierAJ I'm also concerned after seeing evidence of Granzyme B accumulation in inflamed tissue from a few studies... apoptosis may be bypassing CD95 to some degree.
@NToola9 @UniofOxford @fitterhappierAJ Given a choice what may be better- Arginase inhibitor or FAS inhibitor?

@doctorsaluja @UniofOxford I like the JAK/STAT data on Baricitinib. MOA is solid, and timing of treatment makes sense, as the effect on interferons in the critical stage of the disease should be theoretically inconsequential.

Still would like to see something earlier in the disease progression.

@doctorsaluja I'm looking further upstream the chain of cytokine dysregulation. There are too many individual pieces that have been tried, and failed. IE: anti-TNF-a w/ @UniofOxford CATALYST trial, small and limited success with anti-IL-6 in RECOVERY and REMAP-CAP...etc.

Need a master switch.
@NToola9 Would arginase inhibition therefore preserve T cell function and help both in acute and chronic COVID pathology?
@fitterhappierAJ @NToola9 "The more original a discovery the more obvious it seems afterwards." - Arthur Koestler
@AlphaTrader00 @NToola9 It's harder to comprehend and has a larger investigational barrier to entry over other therapies. Note the many trials on convalescent plasma, which had dubious benefit.

@fitterhappierAJ @NToola9 Science moved quickly on certain #COVID19 therapies (vaccines, anti-virals, nAbs) over the past 2 years, while moving at a snails pace on others (hospitalized patients)

The keys to unlock COVID19 pathogenesis have been collecting dust since mid 2020

Why?
https://t.co/EJoWS6M8ET
